messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Count on CFI graphs for #P-hardnessFunded by the European Union (ERC, CountHom, 101077083). Views and opinions expressed are however those of the author(s) only and do not necessarily reflect those of the European Union or the European Research Council Executive Agency. Neither the European Union nor the granting authority can be held responsible for them. The author is also part of BARC, supported by the VILLUM Foundation grant 16582. {textblock}5(8, 10.5)

Paper Abstract: Abstract Given graphs Hğ»H and GğºG, possibly with vertex-colors, a homomorphism is a function f:Vâ€‹(H)â†’Vâ€‹(G):ğ‘“â†’ğ‘‰ğ»ğ‘‰ğºf:V(H)\to V(G) that preserves colors and edges. Many interesting counting problems are finite linear combinations pâ€‹(â‹…)=âˆ‘HÎ±Hâ€‹homâ¡(H,â‹…)ğ‘â‹…subscriptğ»subscriptğ›¼ğ»homğ»â‹…p(\,\cdot\,)=\sum_{H}\alpha_{H}\hom(H,\,\cdot\,) of homomorphism counts from fixed graphs Hğ»H. It is known that such fixed linear combinations are hard to evaluate under standard complexity assumptions if there exists a large-treewidth graph Sğ‘†S with Î±Sâ‰ 0subscriptğ›¼ğ‘†0\alpha_{S}\neq 0. This can be shown in two steps: In the first step, hardness is shown for the problems homâ¡(S,â‹…)homğ‘†â‹…\hom(S,\,\cdot\,) with colorful (i.e., bijectively colored) graphs Sğ‘†S of large treewidth. In the second step, it is shown that homomorphism counts from colorful graphs Sğ‘†S into graphs GğºG can be reduced to evaluating finite linear combinations of homomorphism counts that contain the uncolored version Sâˆ˜superscriptğ‘†S^{\circ} of Sğ‘†S. This second step can be performed via inclusion-exclusion in 2|Eâ€‹(S)|â€‹polyâ€‹(n,s)superscript2ğ¸ğ‘†polyğ‘›ğ‘ 2^{|E(S)|}\mathrm{poly}(n,s) time, where nğ‘›n is the size of GğºG and sğ‘ s is the maximum number of vertices among graphs in the linear combination. This running time is acceptable when Sğ‘†S and sğ‘ s are small compared to nğ‘›n, which is the setting considered in previous works. In this paper, we show that the second step can even be performed in time 4Î”â€‹(S)â€‹polyâ€‹(n,s)superscript4Î”ğ‘†polyğ‘›ğ‘ 4^{\Delta(S)}\mathrm{poly}(n,s), where Î”â€‹(S)Î”ğ‘†\Delta(S) is the maximum degree of Sğ‘†S. Our reduction is based on graph products with Caiâ€“FÃ¼rerâ€“Immerman graphs, a novel technique that is likely of independent interest. If Î”â€‹(S)Î”ğ‘†\Delta(S) is constant and sğ‘ s is polynomial in nğ‘›n, this technique yields a polynomial-time reduction from homâ¡(S,â‹…)homğ‘†â‹…\hom(S,\,\cdot\,) to linear combinations of homomorphism counts involving Sâˆ˜superscriptğ‘†S^{\circ}, even when Sğ‘†S is part of the input. Under certain conditions, it actually suffices that a supergraph Tğ‘‡T of Sâˆ˜superscriptğ‘†S^{\circ} is contained in the target linear combination, which is useful, since large treewidth is witnessed by subgraphs of maximum degree 333. Using the new reduction, we obtain #â€‹ğ–¯#ğ–¯\mathsf{\#P}-hardness results for problems that could previously only be studied under parameterized complexity assumptions that are a priori stronger than â€œclassicalâ€ assumptions. For fixed graph classes â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} satisfying natural polynomial-time enumerability conditions, this includes the problems #â€‹Homâ€‹(â„‹)#Homâ„‹\mathrm{\#Hom}(\mathcal{H}), #â€‹Subâ€‹(â„‹)#Subâ„‹\mathrm{\#Sub}(\mathcal{H}) and #â€‹Indâ€‹(â„‹)#Indâ„‹\mathrm{\#Ind}(\mathcal{H}) of counting, on input a graph Hâˆˆâ„‹ğ»â„‹H\in\mathcal{H} and a general graph GğºG, the homomorphisms from Hğ»H to GğºG, and the subgraph copies and induced subgraph copies of Hğ»H in GğºG. Generally speaking, the new reduction opens up the possibility of transferring techniques from parameterized counting complexity to â€œclassicalâ€ non-parameterized counting complexity.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The pebbling comonad in finite model theory",
        "Approximating the maximum clique minor and some subgraph homeomorphism problems",
        "A systematic study of isomorphism invariants of finite groups via the Weisfeiler-Leman dimension",
        "Exact and approximate pattern counting in degenerate graphs: New algorithms, hardness results, and complexity dichotomies",
        "Current algorithms for detecting subgraphs of bounded treewidth are probably optimal",
        "An optimal lower bound on the number of variables for graph identification",
        "Polynomial bounds for the grid-minor theorem",
        "Counting answers to existential positive queries: A complexity classification",
        "Strong computational lower bounds via parameterized complexity",
        "The hardness of embedding grids and walls",
        "Understanding the complexity of induced subgraph isomorphisms",
        "The simple, little and slow things count: on parameterized counting complexity",
        "Parity separation: A scientifically proven method for permanent weight loss",
        "Homomorphisms are a good basis for counting small subgraphs",
        "Complexity of counting subgraphs: Only the boundedness of the vertex-cover number counts",
        "Parameterizing the permanent: Genus, apices, minors, evaluation mod 2ksuperscript2ğ‘˜2^{k}",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "The complexity of counting homomorphisms seen from the other side",
        "LovÃ¡sz meets Weisfeiler and Leman",
        "Exponential time complexity of the permanent and the Tutte polynomial",
        "The graph isomorphism problem and approximate categories",
        "Counting induced subgraphs: An algebraic approach to #W[1]-hardness",
        "Parameterized Complexity",
        "On recognizing graphs by numbers of homomorphisms",
        "Parameterized Complexity Theory",
        "The Complexity Theory Companion",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "The parameterised complexity of counting connected subgraphs and graph motifs",
        "Some hard families of parameterized counting problems",
        "The parameterised complexity of counting even and odd induced subgraphs",
        "Monotone arithmetic complexity of graph homomorphism polynomials",
        "The parameterized complexity of k-biclique",
        "Large networks and graph limits, volume 60",
        "Can you beat treewidth?",
        "Homomorphism-distinguishing closedness for graphs of bounded tree-width",
        "Parameterized (modular) counting and cayley graph expanders",
        "Oddomorphisms and homomorphism indistinguishability over graphs of bounded degree",
        "Counting restricted homomorphisms via mÃ¶bius inversion over matroid lattices",
        "Counting induced subgraphs: A topological approach to #W[1]-hardness",
        "Counting small induced subgraphs satisfying monotone properties",
        "Detecting and counting small subgraphs, and evaluating a parameterized tutte polynomial: Lower bounds via toroidal grids and cayley graph expanders",
        "The complexity of computing the permanent",
        "A reduction of a graph to a canonical form and an algebra arising during this reduction",
        "On construction and identification of graphs",
        "Finding, minimizing, and counting weighted subgraphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Count on CFI graphs for #P-hardnessFunded by the European Union (ERC, CountHom, 101077083). Views and opinions expressed are however those of the author(s) only and do not necessarily reflect those of the European Union or the European Research Council Executive Agency. Neither the European Union nor the granting authority can be held responsible for them. The author is also part of BARC, supported by the VILLUM Foundation grant 16582. {textblock}5(8, 10.5), providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
